content: The Act is titled the "Technology Retraining and Investment Now Act for the 21st Century". It includes findings and purposes. The Technology Retraining and Investment Now Act for the 21st Century includes findings that highlight the importance of educational and training investments in knowledge workers, noting a disparity in investment between the United States and its trading partners. The declining educational performance of students in the United States compared to other countries is creating a disparity. This makes it difficult for US businesses to fund worker education and training, which is provided at no cost for workers in other countries. The global workforce environment is pressuring domestic companies to utilize highly educated knowledge workers from other countries. The United States is facing a challenge with declining educational performance compared to other countries, leading to pressure on domestic companies to use highly educated knowledge workers from other countries. It is crucial for the government to reverse this trend to protect national security, the middle class, and the welfare of workers, while also ensuring global competitiveness. Public-private partnerships, like the research and development tax credit, can help address these issues effectively. Section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 emphasizes maximizing sector strengths, reducing development risk, and improving cost effectiveness. Businesses play a crucial role in training the workforce for available jobs and developing new training methods. With a significant number of baby boomers retiring in the next 20 years, the US must ensure it can train its workforce for high-paying jobs. The Act aims to encourage businesses and individuals to support the educational development of knowledge workers in the US by providing incentives for information and communications technology education and training investments. This will help train the workforce for high-paying jobs and support benefit programs for retirees. The Act aims to encourage businesses to invest in training for workers in fields like information technology, engineering, and manufacturing to maximize their skills and support business growth. The Act encourages businesses to invest in training for workers in information technology, engineering, and manufacturing to enhance skills and support business growth. Additionally, a new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code to provide credit for information and communications technology education and training program expenses. The Act introduces a credit for information and communications technology education and training program expenses, allowing a 50 percent credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year. This credit applies to expenses incurred for the benefit of employees or individuals not engaged in a trade or business. The Act allows employers to receive a credit for employee expenses by assigning the employee's limitation under subsection (b). The maximum expense amount per individual is $4,000, with a potential increase to $5,000 for certain programs and individuals. The maximum expense amount per individual is $4,000, with a potential increase to $5,000 for certain programs and individuals, such as those in empowerment zones, enterprise communities, renewal communities, or school districts with at least 50% of students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches. The Act allows employers to receive a credit for employee expenses in designated disaster areas, rural enterprise communities, or other specified zones. The Act provides a credit for employee expenses in designated disaster areas, rural enterprise communities, Rural Economic Area Partnership Zones, and areas under Indian tribal government jurisdiction. The term 'information technology education and training program expenses' refers to expenses incurred by the taxpayer for participation in such programs. Expenses incurred for participation in information and communications technology education and training programs include course work, certification testing, programs registered by the Department of Labor, and other essential skill assessment expenses. The term 'information technology education and training program' refers to training in IT workplace disciplines provided by accredited institutions or employers. Commercial IT training is also included. The curr_chunk defines 'commercial information technology training provider' as a private sector organization offering ICT education. It also defines 'employer-owned information technology training organization' as a private sector entity providing IT training to employees using internal resources. Training programs must adhere to industry-recognized disciplines and evaluation methods, comparable to other training providers. No double benefits are allowed, disallowing deductions or credits under other provisions. The credit amount is reduced by information technology education and training expenses. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 30D outlines information and communications technology education and training program expenses. The amendments apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4 defines eligible educational institutions. The term 'eligible educational institution' is defined as an institution described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible to participate in a program under title IV of such Act. The amendment defines a commercial information and communications technology training provider. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2006. SEC. 5. INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TRAINING CERTIFICATION ADVISORY BOARD. Establishment of Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board with up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury from IT certification and training associations and businesses. Board to meet at least annually and elect a Chairperson from its members. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board, established with up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury, must elect a Chairperson from its members. The Chairperson must be a member of an information technology industry trade association. The Board is responsible for developing guidelines for computer science and related subjects for college courses, as well as a list of IT training and certifications eligible for tax credits under the Internal Revenue Code. The Board must submit this list annually by October 1st. The Board shall submit the required list to the Secretary of the Treasury annually. Board members serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Board is not subject to termination under the Federal Advisory Committee Act.
